repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
With `CYTHON_COMPILING_IN_LIMITED_API` enabled the generated code kept the result of `PyModule_Create` in a temporary that was decremented before the function returned even though the module init function must return a new reference.

This extends the scope of `module_temp` to the whole init function and removes the `DECREF`.

comment_data.body: This leaks a reference to the module now if it fails. That's pretty much why we use managed references also for temps. Or the global module reference.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3255,17 +3257,17 @@ def generate_module_creation_code(self, env, code):
                 env.module_cname))
         code.putln(code.error_goto_if_null(env.module_cname, self.pos))
         code.putln("#elif CYTHON_COMPILING_IN_LIMITED_API")
-        module_temp = code.funcstate.allocate_temp(py_object_type, manage_ref=True)
+        code.putln("{")
+        module_temp = "module"
         code.putln(
-            "%s = PyModule_Create(&%s); %s" % (
+            "PyObject *%s = PyModule_Create(&%s); %s" % (
                 module_temp,
                 Naming.pymoduledef_cname,
                 code.error_goto_if_null(module_temp, self.pos)))
-        code.put_gotref(module_temp, py_object_type)
         code.putln(code.error_goto_if_neg("PyState_AddModule(%s, &%s)" % (
             module_temp, Naming.pymoduledef_cname), self.pos))

comment_data.body:
The temp is never freed.

I think there should be some guard in Cython's infrastructure against this case that should just bark loudly.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3239,6 +3241,7 @@ def generate_module_creation_code(self, env, code):
         else:
             doc = "0"
 
+        module_temp = code.funcstate.allocate_temp(py_object_type, manage_ref=True)

comment_data.body: This could be taken out of the `#if` guards now, right?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3248,32 +3251,29 @@ def generate_module_creation_code(self, env, code):
         code.putln("#if PY_MAJOR_VERSION < 3")
         code.putln(
             '%s = Py_InitModule4(%s, %s, %s, 0, PYTHON_API_VERSION); Py_XINCREF(%s);' % (
-                env.module_cname,
+                module_temp,
                 env.module_name.as_c_string_literal(),
                 env.method_table_cname,
                 doc,
-                env.module_cname))
-        code.putln(code.error_goto_if_null(env.module_cname, self.pos))
-        code.putln("#elif CYTHON_COMPILING_IN_LIMITED_API")
-        module_temp = code.funcstate.allocate_temp(py_object_type, manage_ref=True)
-        code.putln(
-            "%s = PyModule_Create(&%s); %s" % (
-                module_temp,
-                Naming.pymoduledef_cname,
-                code.error_goto_if_null(module_temp, self.pos)))
-        code.put_gotref(module_temp, py_object_type)
-        code.putln(code.error_goto_if_neg("PyState_AddModule(%s, &%s)" % (
-            module_temp, Naming.pymoduledef_cname), self.pos))
-        code.put_decref_clear(module_temp, type=py_object_type)
-        code.funcstate.release_temp(module_temp)
+                module_temp))
+        code.putln(code.error_goto_if_null(module_temp, self.pos))

comment_data.body: We need the extra reference because we return the module from the init function. I can go back to code that looks more like my earlier attempt where I let the module_temp live longer and use it in the return.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3239,6 +3241,7 @@ def generate_module_creation_code(self, env, code):
         else:
             doc = "0"
 
+        module_temp = code.funcstate.allocate_temp(py_object_type, manage_ref=True)

comment_data.body: Actually the code is simplest as is. Anyway is there anyway to make it more obvious to the reader that the ownership of the module is transfered to the returning code via return and stored in the meantime stored in `Naming.module_cname`?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3239,6 +3241,7 @@ def generate_module_creation_code(self, env, code):
         else:
             doc = "0"
 
+        module_temp = code.funcstate.allocate_temp(py_object_type, manage_ref=True)

comment_data.body:
In any case, this lacks a `release_temp()`. And the two cases are different. One passes the reference on to `module_cname`, the other just overwrites it with `NULL` and leaks it. What should happen with the reference in the limited API case?

It's often easier to look through the code paths in the generated C code than in the generator to validate if the references are handled correctly in all of them.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3250,32 +3251,28 @@ def generate_module_creation_code(self, env, code):
         code.putln("#if PY_MAJOR_VERSION < 3")
         code.putln(
             '%s = Py_InitModule4(%s, %s, %s, 0, PYTHON_API_VERSION); Py_XINCREF(%s);' % (
-                env.module_cname,
+                module_temp,
                 env.module_name.as_c_string_literal(),
                 env.method_table_cname,
                 doc,
-                env.module_cname))
-        code.putln(code.error_goto_if_null(env.module_cname, self.pos))
-        code.putln("#elif CYTHON_COMPILING_IN_LIMITED_API")
-        module_temp = code.funcstate.allocate_temp(py_object_type, manage_ref=True)
-        code.putln(
-            "%s = PyModule_Create(&%s); %s" % (
-                module_temp,
-                Naming.pymoduledef_cname,
-                code.error_goto_if_null(module_temp, self.pos)))
-        code.put_gotref(module_temp, py_object_type)
-        code.putln(code.error_goto_if_neg("PyState_AddModule(%s, &%s)" % (
-            module_temp, Naming.pymoduledef_cname), self.pos))
-        code.put_decref_clear(module_temp, type=py_object_type)
-        code.funcstate.release_temp(module_temp)
+                module_temp))
         code.putln('#else')
         code.putln(
             "%s = PyModule_Create(&%s);" % (
-                env.module_cname,
+                module_temp,
                 Naming.pymoduledef_cname))
-        code.putln(code.error_goto_if_null(env.module_cname, self.pos))
         code.putln("#endif")
-        code.putln("#endif")  # CYTHON_PEP489_MULTI_PHASE_INIT
+        code.putln(code.error_goto_if_null(module_temp, self.pos))
+
+        code.putln("#if !CYTHON_COMPILING_IN_LIMITED_API")
+        code.putln("%s = %s;" % (Naming.module_cname, module_temp))
+        code.putln("#else")
+        code.putln(code.error_goto_if_neg("PyState_AddModule(%s, &%s)" % (
+            module_temp, Naming.pymoduledef_cname), self.pos))
+        code.putln("#endif")
+        code.putln("%s = NULL;" % module_temp)

comment_data.body:
The only difference between "normal" and the limited variant should be replacing the assignment to `Naming.pymoduledef_cname` with a call to `PyState_AddModule`.

The `= NULL;` assignment comes after either the `PyState_AddModule` or the assignment to `Naming.pymoduledef_cname` have been performed. The ownership is sorta transfered to those systems until the `return` happens (the existing code is structured in this odd way where the `return` is in the calling function and not immediately in `generate_module_creation_code`)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3250,32 +3251,28 @@ def generate_module_creation_code(self, env, code):
         code.putln("#if PY_MAJOR_VERSION < 3")
         code.putln(
             '%s = Py_InitModule4(%s, %s, %s, 0, PYTHON_API_VERSION); Py_XINCREF(%s);' % (
-                env.module_cname,
+                module_temp,
                 env.module_name.as_c_string_literal(),
                 env.method_table_cname,
                 doc,
-                env.module_cname))
-        code.putln(code.error_goto_if_null(env.module_cname, self.pos))
-        code.putln("#elif CYTHON_COMPILING_IN_LIMITED_API")
-        module_temp = code.funcstate.allocate_temp(py_object_type, manage_ref=True)
-        code.putln(
-            "%s = PyModule_Create(&%s); %s" % (
-                module_temp,
-                Naming.pymoduledef_cname,
-                code.error_goto_if_null(module_temp, self.pos)))
-        code.put_gotref(module_temp, py_object_type)
-        code.putln(code.error_goto_if_neg("PyState_AddModule(%s, &%s)" % (
-            module_temp, Naming.pymoduledef_cname), self.pos))
-        code.put_decref_clear(module_temp, type=py_object_type)
-        code.funcstate.release_temp(module_temp)
+                module_temp))
         code.putln('#else')
         code.putln(
             "%s = PyModule_Create(&%s);" % (
-                env.module_cname,
+                module_temp,
                 Naming.pymoduledef_cname))
-        code.putln(code.error_goto_if_null(env.module_cname, self.pos))
         code.putln("#endif")
-        code.putln("#endif")  # CYTHON_PEP489_MULTI_PHASE_INIT
+        code.putln(code.error_goto_if_null(module_temp, self.pos))
+
+        code.putln("#if !CYTHON_COMPILING_IN_LIMITED_API")
+        code.putln("%s = %s;" % (Naming.module_cname, module_temp))
+        code.putln("#else")
+        code.putln(code.error_goto_if_neg("PyState_AddModule(%s, &%s)" % (
+            module_temp, Naming.pymoduledef_cname), self.pos))
+        code.putln("#endif")
+        code.putln("%s = NULL;" % module_temp)

commit.message: Avoid unused variable warning in generated mp_ass_subscript

Increment result of module init function

Summary: Fix problem where the code generated for the limited API would not increment the module before returning it from the PyInit function (and decref the temporary that held the result of `PyModule_Create`). Fix this by keeping the module in the temporary throughout the function and using it for the `return` as well.

Based on Facebook D21894032

repo.description: Fork to work on limited API (aka PEP384 / stable ABI) support
repo.name: cython

milestone.description:
Goals:
– New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
– Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3str`.
– Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
– Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: Fix module init reference counting when CYTHON_COMPILING_IN_LIMITED_API
